impregnated W and Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts.\"", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations, particularly in processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions. A new methane partial oxidation (MPO) catalyst was prepared by grafting MoO2(acac)2 onto the surface of dried HZSM-5 zeolite. After the grafting reaction, the solid was washed, dried, and calcined in air to afford the final [S]O2MoO2, Mo(VI), highly dispersed, surface species. The catalytic activity of this new material in the MPO reaction is enhanced in comparison with the classical Mo,W/HZSM-5 impregnation catalysts. The conversion of methane into organic compounds of greater interest is of significant scientific and industrial relevance due to the large natural gas reserves, of which methane is the principal component. Transformation of methane into methanol or formaldehyde is a very attractive process since the former compound can be converted into liquid fuels similar to gasoline, and the latter is a key component in a number of synthetic organic methods. The weakness of the CH bond of methane, caused by distortion of the methane molecule through its interaction with the zeolite surface, has been proposed as the first step in the methane activation mechanism. Formaldehyde selectivity was dependent on the dispersion and the nature of the metal oxide supported phase. Grafting of transition metal complexes onto reactive surface structures is an expeditious alternative method to obtain catalytic systems with definable structure and composition, offering potential for the design of efficient catalysts with an advantageous combination of specific properties of both homogeneous and heterogeneous systems. The UV diffuse reflectance spectra of the samples exhibit absorption bands near 240 nm due to ligand-to-metal charge transfer transitions, in accordance with the presence of the proposed MoO42molybdenum(VI) species on the surface. XPS analysis indicates the presence of highly dispersed molybdenum(VI) species. The XRD spectra of the catalysts were registered and compared to those of the pure support, MoO2(acac)2, and MoO3, showing that the reaction between the complex and the surface OH groups allows us to obtain highly dispersed oxo species. In the case of aqueous impregnation, aggregates of MoO3 are usually detected. The relatively high values of CO selectivity for the two Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts can be attributed to the presence of residual acid sites on the zeolite surface. The high degree of surface covering in the W/HZSM-5 catalyst leads to a lower CO selectivity. A new catalyst for the MPO reaction was obtained by grafting MoO2(acac)2 onto the surface of the HZSM-5 zeolite, resulting in isolated oxo species of molybdenum in oxidation state VI with a large dispersion. The specific activity of these isolated MoO42species greatly improves the formaldehyde yield in the methane partial oxidation reaction.", "Doi": "10.1016/s0926-860x(99)00423-8"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "The literature does not provide specific information on how the composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations, particularly in processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions, and what factors contribute to their industrial significance. However, it does discuss the quantum chemical study of mechanisms for oxidative dehydrogenation of propane on vanadium oxide, which is of great interest in industrial catalysis. The study found that the potential energy surface has large barriers, which are lowered somewhat when the possibility of a triplet state is considered. The barriers on the reaction pathway are 45-80 kcal/mol above the energy of the reactants, which are much larger than found experimentally for propane ODH on supported vanadia. Some of the barriers may be reduced by consideration of more complex reactions, such as a concerted reaction involving adsorption of O2 during water elimination. The reduction of other barriers, such as for propane adsorption, appears to require the involvement of a support for the vanadium oxide catalyst.", "Doi": "10.1021/jp056228w"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The conversion of light alkanes to more useful products. The catalytic conversion of methane in particular to methanol [ 1, 21 or higher hydrocarbons [ 3-51 has received much attention.\"\n          [2] \"In con- trast, the conversion of higher alkanes, such as C&/C, cuts, can proceed in the absence of such co-reactants.\"\n          [3] \"Catalytic dehydrogenation of propane and butane to alkenes is at the heart of processes such as Oleflex [ 71, Aromatization processes such as Cyclar [ 8, 91 and MB-forming [lo] have also recently been announced.\"\n          [4] \"These processes of- fer a means of converting light gases to aromatics, especially BTX,and are based on the use of catalysts such as ZSM-5 and related materials.\"\n          [5] \"The conversion of light alkanes such as propane and butane to aromatics is not completely selective. Light alkenes, the probable reaction intermediates,are formed in addition to the BTX components.\"\n          [6] \"On Zn-ZSM-5 part of the hydrogen atom pool lost on aromatization is re- leased as dihydrogen [ 111 and an improved BTX selectivity results.\"\n          [7] \"It appears [ 121 that Ga-ZSM-5 or GaZn-ZSM-5 catalysts operate in a similar manner,but gallium-containing samples are preferred since zinc volatilization occurs at the reaction temperatures used for samples containing zinc alone.\"", "English": "The conversion of light alkanes to more useful products has received much attention, particularly the catalytic conversion of methane to methanol or higher hydrocarbons. Higher alkanes, such as C&/C, can be converted without co-reactants. Catalytic dehydrogenation of propane and butane to alkenes is central to processes like Oleflex, Cyclar, and MB-forming, which convert light gases to aromatics, especially BTX, using catalysts like ZSM-5. The conversion of light alkanes to aromatics is not completely selective, with light alkenes also being formed. On Zn-ZSM-5, part of the hydrogen lost during aromatization is released as dihydrogen, improving BTX selectivity. Ga-ZSM-5 or GaZn-ZSM-5 catalysts operate similarly, with gallium-containing samples preferred due to zinc volatilization at reaction temperatures.", "Doi": "10.1016/s0166-9834(00)80384-x"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "The literature does not provide specific information on how the composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. However, it does discuss the regioselective H/D exchange of propane on Zn/H-MFI zeolite, which is a type of metal-exchanged zeolite. The study shows that the incorporated Zn2+ cations act as strong Lewis sites and change the mechanism of alkane activation and transformation, favoring hydrogen removal. The regioselectivity of the exchange is attributed to two proposed mechanisms: (i) propane dehydrogenation on Zn-sites followed by protonation of propene by acidic OH groups in accordance with Markovnikov's rule and abstraction of deuteride ion from another propane molecule; (ii) the reversible heterolytic dissociative adsorption of propane to form Zn-propyl species and acidic OH groups. The study also indicates that the modification of the zeolite with Zn changes the mechanism of the exchange, leading to regioselectivity in the methyl groups of propane. The kinetic parameters for the H/D exchange in propane-d8 on Zn/H-MFI are different from those reported for H-MFI and sulfated zirconia, suggesting an alternative mechanism of H/D exchange reaction for propane on Zn/H-MFI.", "Doi": "10.1007/s10562-007-9044-6"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"ROLE OF VANADIUM AS THE PREFERRED ELEMENT IN CATALYSTS FOR SELECTIVE OXIDATION OF ALKANES .\"\n          [2] \"ROLE OF THE ISOLATION OF VANADIUM IONS IN A QUASI-INERT MATRIX\"\n          [3] \"ROLE OF THE STABILITY OF THE PRODUCT .\"\n          [4] \"ROLE OF MULTIFUNCTIONALITY .\"\n          [5] \"A. Multifunctionality as a Criterion in Catalyst Design . .\"\n          [6] \"B. Multifunctionality as a Tool to Explain the Reaction Mechanism\"\n          [7] \"C. Inadequacy of Multifunctionality Alone .\"\n          [8] \"ROLE OF THE TYPE OF C-H BOND ACTIVATION .\"\n          [9] \"ROLE OF ACIDITY AND BASICITY .\"", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, play significant roles in the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. Vanadium is the preferred element in catalysts for selective oxidation of alkanes. The isolation of vanadium ions in a quasi-inert matrix is crucial. The stability of the product, multifunctionality, the type of C-H bond activation, and the role of acidity and basicity also contribute to the efficiency of these processes. Multifunctionality can be used as a criterion in catalyst design and as a tool to explain the reaction mechanism, but it is not adequate alone. These factors are essential for the industrial significance of oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions.", "Doi": "10.1080/01614949608006463"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "The literature does not provide specific information on how the composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. However, it does discuss the role of zinc-modified H-MFI catalysts in propane activation. The study found that the initial step of propane conversion over Zn-containing zeolites is dissociative adsorption over Zn oxide species, leading to the formation of propyl zinc species and ZnOH groups. The subsequent dehydrogenation of propyl groups and recombination of hydrogen over Zn sites leads to propylene and dihydrogen formation and regeneration of an active catalytic site. Propylene undergoes further oligomerization over the neighbouring acidic site, whereas dihydrogen may participate in propane hydrogenolysis under certain reaction conditions. The recombinative hydrogen desorption shifts the reaction equilibrium toward propylene formation, which further undergoes oligomerization, cyclization, and aromatization, accounting for the higher aromatization activity of Zn-containing zeolites with respect to pure acidic sites. The efficiency of this process is influenced by the partial pressure of reactants, with hydrogen evolution favored at low pressures and hydrogenolysis preferred at high pressures. The industrial significance of these catalysts lies in their ability to convert light alkanes to aromatics, which are important petrochemical feedstocks.", "Doi": "10.1016/j.jcat.2005.11.037"},
{"Quotes": "The catalytic conversion of methane to desired chemical products or liquid fuel is not only a promising approach for the utilization of natural gas resource but also a great challenge to catalysis science.\n          The Mo modified ZSM-5 catalysts exhibited excellent catalytic activity and selectivity to benzene for the conversion of methane at 973 K under non-oxidizing conditions.\n          The Mo or Zn loaded in the ZSM-5 played a significant role in methane activation.\n          The yield of benzene increased with increasing partial pressure of methane.\n          The dehydrogenation and aromatization of methane on modified ZSM-5 zeolite catalysts has been studied under non-oxidizing conditions with a fixed bed continuous-flow reactor and with a temperature programmed reactor.\n          The catalytic activity of ZSM-5 is greatly improved by incorporating a metal cation (Mo or Zn).\n          A carbenium ion mechanism for the activation of methane is suggested.", "English": "The catalytic conversion of methane to desired chemical products or liquid fuel is a promising approach for the utilization of natural gas resources and a significant challenge for catalysis science. Mo modified ZSM-5 catalysts show excellent catalytic activity and selectivity to benzene for the conversion of methane at 973 K under non-oxidizing conditions. The incorporation of Mo or Zn in ZSM-5 plays a significant role in methane activation. The yield of benzene increases with increasing partial pressure of methane. The composition and structure of metal-based catalysts, such as modified ZSM-5 zeolites with incorporated Mo or Zn, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. The catalytic activity of ZSM-5 is enhanced by the addition of metal cations, leading to improved dehydrogenation and aromatization of methane under non-oxidizing conditions. The reaction conditions, including temperature and the presence of a carbenium ion mechanism, contribute to the industrial significance of these catalysts by enabling the conversion of methane to benzene with high selectivity and stability. These factors contribute to the industrial significance of metal-based catalysts in alkane transformations.", "Doi": "10.1007/bf00767368"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations, particularly in processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions. The study of propane oxidative dehydrogenation on single-crystal V2O5(001) by periodic density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveals that the CH bond of propane can be activated by both the terminal and the bridging lattice O atoms on the surface with similar activation energies. At the terminal O site, both the radical and the oxo-insertion pathways are likely for the CH bond activation, while only the oxo-insertion mechanism is feasible at the bridging O site. The propene production from the propoxide at the bridging O site is much easier due to the weaker binding of propoxide at the bridging O. It is concluded that single-crystal V2O5(001) is not a good catalyst due to the terminal O being too active to release propene. An efficient catalyst for the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) reaction has to make a compromise between the ability to activate the CH bond and the ability to release propene. The industrial significance of these catalysts lies in their ability to convert inexpensive raw materials like alkanes into more valuable products like olefins through selective oxidation, which is a promising solution to meet the ever-increasing worldwide demand for olefins.", "Doi": "10.1021/ja0611745"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"On two alternative mechanisms of ethane activation over ZSM-5 zeolite modified by Zn21 and Ga11 cations\"\n          [2] \"The activation of ethane over zinc- and gallium-modified HZSM-5 dehydrogenation catalysts was studied by diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy.\"\n          [3] \"Hydrocarbon activation on HZSM-5 modified by bivalent Zn and univalent Ga cations proceeds via two distinctly different mechanisms.\"\n          [4] \"The stronger molecular adsorption of ethane by the acidbase pairs formed by distantly separated cationic Zn21 and basic oxygen sites results already at room temperature in strong polarizability of adsorbed ethane and subsequent heterolytic dissociative adsorption at moderate temperatures.\"\n          [5] \"In contrast, molecular adsorption of ethane on Ga1 cations is weak.\"\n          [6] \"At high temperatures dissociative hydrocarbon adsorption takes place, resulting in the formation of ethyl and hydride fragments coordinating to the cationic gallium species.\"\n          [7] \"Whereas in the zinc case a Brnsted acid proton is formed upon ethane dissociation, decomposition of the ethyl fragment on gallium results in gallium dihydride species and does not lead to Brnsted acid protons.\"\n          [8] \"This difference in alkane activation has direct consequences for hydrocarbon conversions involving dehydrogenation.\"", "English": "The mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations, particularly in processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions, are influenced by the composition and structure of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites. The study of ethane activation over zinc- and gallium-modified HZSM-5 dehydrogenation catalysts by diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy reveals two distinctly different mechanisms. The stronger molecular adsorption of ethane by the acidbase pairs formed by distantly separated cationic Zn21 and basic oxygen sites results in strong polarizability of adsorbed ethane and subsequent heterolytic dissociative adsorption at moderate temperatures. In contrast, molecular adsorption of ethane on Ga1 cations is weak, and at high temperatures, dissociative hydrocarbon adsorption takes place, resulting in the formation of ethyl and hydride fragments coordinating to the cationic gallium species. The formation of Brnsted acid protons upon ethane dissociation in the zinc case contrasts with the formation of gallium dihydride species and the absence of Brnsted acid protons in the gallium case. This difference in alkane activation has direct consequences for hydrocarbon conversions involving dehydrogenation, influencing the efficiency and selectivity of the reactions. The industrial significance of these catalysts lies in their ability to selectively convert alkanes into more valuable products, such as ethylene, through dehydrogenation processes.", "Doi": "10.1039/b506782k"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "The literature does not provide specific information on how the composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. However, it does mention that catalyst development has played a crucial role in the advances of methane conversion processes, and that there remains a need for catalysts that promote higher selectivity to the desired product and have a longer life. The literature also discusses the use of certain catalysts, such as FePO4 for the production of CH3OH and HCHO, and Mo/H-ZSM-5 zeolite for the conversion of methane to aromatics. The efficiency and selectivity of these catalysts are influenced by factors such as pretreatment conditions, reaction temperature, the presence of certain additives, the state and location of the active form of the metal, and the presence of other compounds in the feed.", "Doi": "10.1016/s0920-5861(00)00456-9"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The effects of support (Al2O3, SiO2, HfO2, TiO2, and ZrO2) on the structure and catalytic behavior of supported vanadia in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane were examined over a wide range of vanadium surface densities (0.515.0 VOx/nm2).\"\n          [2] \"X-ray diffrac- tion and Raman and UV-visible spectra showed that vanadia exists as highly dispersed species at surface densities below 7 VOx/nm2 on Al2O3, HfO2, TiO2, and ZrO2, but as large V2O5 crystallites on SiO2.\"\n          [3] \"Surface structures evolve from isolated monovanadates to polyvanadate domains and V2O5 crystallites as VOx surface density increases.\"\n          [4] \"Polyvanadates appear at lower surface densities on ZrO2 and TiO2 than on Al2O3 and HfO2.\"\n          [5] \"UV-visible edge energies decrease as VOx domains grow with increasing VOx surface density on all supports.\"\n          [6] \"Initial propene selectivities increase with increasing VOx surface density, as monovanadate species and exposed support sites, which favor primary combustion pathways, decrease in con- centration.\"\n          [7] \"Oxidative dehydrogenation rates per V-atom reach a maximum on VOx domains of intermediate size, which provide a balance between the activity of surface VOx species and their acces- sibility to reactants.\"\n          [8] \"Interactions with supports determine the type of VOx structures present at a given surface density, but turnover rates do not depend on the identity of the support when differences in VOx structure are taken into account.\"\n          [9] \"Oxidative dehydrogenation turnover rates are similar on polyvanadate species and on surface VOx sites on bulk V2O5.\"\n          [10] \"The relative rates of oxidative dehydro- genation to form propene and of secondary propene oxidation to COx do not depend on the identity of the support or on VOx sur- face density or structure.\"", "English": "The structure and catalytic behavior of supported vanadia in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane are influenced by the type of support (Al2O3, SiO2, HfO2, TiO2, and ZrO2) and the vanadium surface density. Vanadia exists as highly dispersed species at surface densities below 7 VOx/nm2 on Al2O3, HfO2, TiO2, and ZrO2, but as large V2O5 crystallites on SiO2. Surface structures evolve from isolated monovanadates to polyvanadate domains and V2O5 crystallites as VOx surface density increases. Polyvanadates appear at lower surface densities on ZrO2 and TiO2 than on Al2O3 and HfO2. UV-visible edge energies decrease as VOx domains grow with increasing VOx surface density on all supports. Initial propene selectivities increase with increasing VOx surface density, as monovanadate species and exposed support sites, which favor primary combustion pathways, decrease in concentration. Oxidative dehydrogenation rates per V-atom reach a maximum on VOx domains of intermediate size, which provide a balance between the activity of surface VOx species and their accessibility to reactants. Interactions with supports determine the type of VOx structures present at a given surface density, but turnover rates do not depend on the identity of the support when differences in VOx structure are taken into account. Oxidative dehydrogenation turnover rates are similar on polyvanadate species and on surface VOx sites on bulk V2O5. The relative rates of oxidative dehydrogenation to form propene and of secondary propene oxidation to COx do not depend on the identity of the support or on VOx surface density or structure. These findings contribute to the understanding of how the composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides, influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations, particularly in processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation.", "Doi": "10.1006/jcat.1998.2295"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The zinc-exchanged (ZSM-5-Zn) and proton-exchanged (ZSM-5-H) forms of ZSM-5 zeolite have been studied for the conversion of propane to aromatic hydrocarbons at temperatures in the range 730-820 K. ZSM-5-Zn was the more active and gave the better BTX selectivity (60-7OC%).\"\n          [2] \"The main features of the conversion mechanism are proposed involving propane dehydrogenation,followed by oligomerization and aromatization.\"\n          [3] \"Cracking to Cl-C2 products is a concurrent reaction. The primary dehydrogenation reaction is mechanistically different on the two types of catalyst: over ZSM-5-H dehydrogenat- ion is rate controlled,while over ZSM-5-Zn this step is in quasi-equilibrium.\"\n          [4] \"The way in which ZSM-5-H might be able to initiate a radical-chain reaction remains a matter for conjecture.\"\n          [5] \"ZSM-5-H and ZSM-5-Zn show quite different dependences of selectivity upon space velocity (c.f. Figures 1 and 2).\"\n          [6] \"We suggest that over ZSM-5-Zn the relatively high rate of hydrogen diffusion in the zeolite channels results in in- creasing depletion of the local hydrogen concentration with increasing space velocity, thus moving the equilibrium in the direction of BTX formation.\"\n          [7] \"The present results suggest that part of the C,-C3 hydrocarbon product formed in propane conversion over the present ZSM-5 catalysts,particularly ZSM-5-Zn,may have arisen from secondary demethylation reactions of aromatic products.\"\n          [8] \"The apparent activation energies, obtained from Arrhenius plots of the propane conversions,were ZSM-5-Zn (I.28 wt% aluminium),121+15 kJ mol-'; ZSM-5-Zn (0.71 wt% aluminium),104+15 kJ mol-'; ZSM-5-H (1.28 wt% aluminium),120t15 kJ mol-'.\"\n          [9] \"Over ZSM-5-Zn the BTX selectivity increased to a small extent.\"\n          [10] \"The way in which ZSM-5-H might be able to initiate a radical-chain reaction remains a matter for conjecture.\"\n          [11] \"However, it is known [lZ] that adsorption of aromatics or olefins on high silica zeolites can involve electron transfer pro- cesses and the generation of some radical species which can be detected by EPR.\"\n          [12] \"We suggest that this different behaviour compared with the protonic form of the catalyst has its origin in the basically different aromatization mechanisms.\"\n          [13] \"As pointed out in the previous discussion,aromatization on ZSM-5-Zn generates hydrogen, as opposed to the hydride transfer mechanism which operates over ZSM-5-H (and which generates paraffins).\"\n          [14] \"We suggest that over ZSM-5-Zn the BTX-forming dehydrogenation process is in quasi-equilibrium (while over ZSM-5-H it is not), also provides an explanation for the different behaviour of the BTX selectivity with changing space velocity over the two catalysts.\"\n          [15] \"The present results suggest that part of the C,-C3 hydrocarbon product formed in propane conversion over the present ZSM-5 catalysts,particularly ZSM-5-Zn,may have arisen from secondary demethylation reactions of aromatic products.\"", "English": "The zinc-exchanged (ZSM-5-Zn) and proton-exchanged (ZSM-5-H) forms of ZSM-5 zeolite have been studied for the conversion of propane to aromatic hydrocarbons at temperatures in the range 730-820 K. ZSM-5-Zn was the more active and gave the better BTX selectivity. The main features of the conversion mechanism involve propane dehydrogenation, followed by oligomerization and aromatization. Cracking to Cl-C2 products is a concurrent reaction. The primary dehydrogenation reaction is mechanistically different on the two types of catalyst: over ZSM-5-H dehydrogenation is rate controlled, while over ZSM-5-Zn this step is in quasi-equilibrium. The apparent activation energies for propane conversions were 121+15 kJ mol-1 for ZSM-5-Zn (1.28 wt% aluminium), 104+15 kJ mol-1 for ZSM-5-Zn (0.71 wt% aluminium), and 120+15 kJ mol-1 for ZSM-5-H (1.28 wt% aluminium). Over ZSM-5-Zn, the BTX selectivity increased slightly. The way in which ZSM-5-H might be able to initiate a radical-chain reaction remains speculative. However, it is known that adsorption of aromatics or olefins on high silica zeolites can involve electron transfer processes and the generation of some radical species which can be detected by EPR. The different behavior compared with the protonic form of the catalyst has its origin in the basically different aromatization mechanisms. Aromatization on ZSM-5-Zn generates hydrogen, as opposed to the hydride transfer mechanism which operates over ZSM-5-H (and which generates paraffins). The present results suggest that part of the C,-C3 hydrocarbon product formed in propane conversion over the present ZSM-5 catalysts, particularly ZSM-5-Zn, may have arisen from secondary demethylation reactions of aromatic products.", "Doi": "10.1016/s0166-9834(00)82709-8"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"Effects of pretreatments on state of gallium and aromatization activity of gallium/ZSM-5 catalysts\"\n          [2] \"The gallium in ion-exchanged ZSM-5, both with and without additional Ga203,can be reduced to Ga+, in the former case up to a limit determined by the number of anionic framework sites.\"\n          [3] \"An ion-exchanged,reduced catalyst exhibits similar redox behavior,and is as active for propane aromatization,as catalysts prepared from purely physical mixtures of Ga203 and H- ZSM-5.\"\n          [4] \"Although reduction generates dispersed,active gallium species in zeolite channels,it is shown that for ethane dehydrogenation to aromatics the reduced (with hydrogen) Ga/ZSM-5 catalysts are not as active or selective as are materials which have been substantially reoxidized either by air or by traces of oxygen in inert gases.\"\n          [5] \"A combination of thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) , differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), and X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies has been used to confirm that rapid reoxi- dation takes place at 550C.\"\n          [6] \"However,the reoxidation does not regenerate /I-GasO,,but rather a higher energy,dispersed Ga3+ which appears to be optimal for production of aromatics from ethane.\"\n          [7] \"This form of Ga3+ is stable under reaction conditions typical of ethane dehydrogenation,but can be reduced by hydrogen.\"\n          [8] \"Keywords: Aromatization,gallium,zeolites,ZSM-5.\"\n          [9] \"Our recent work on gallium-containing MFI catalysts for light alkane aro- matization has led us to the conclusion that hydrogen-reduced Ga,O,/ZSM-5 mixtures, with a least some Gal+ in the starting material, is very active and selective for propane aromatization.\"\n          [10] \"This conclusion is based upon the obser- vations that: (1) selectivities and activities for aromatics production from pro- pane were greatly improved with hydrogen pretreatment [ 1,2]; (2) we were unable to detect gallium insertion into the zeolitic framework upon reduction [2]; and (3) we have been able to correlate hydrogen reduction of Ga,O,/H- ZSM-5 mechanical mixtures and Ga ( NOs),/H-ZSM-5 impregnated materials\"\n          [11] \"It is generally agreed that the primary role of extra-framework gallium in these materials is to enhance rates of alkene,diene,or cycloalkene dehydro- genation [5-81.\"\n          [12] \"High surface area GazO, and steamed gallosilicates by them- selves can aromatize aliphatic dienes,1-hexene,and cyclohexene at significant rates over the temperature range 500-600 C [ 7,8].\"\n          [13] \"Therefore the dispersion and the oxidation state of gallium within zeolite channels should greatly affect the relative rates of alkane dehydrogenation and hydrocracking;the aromat- ics/methane selectivity ratio should be a good indicator of these relative rates.\"\n          [14] \"In order to distinguish more clearly the effects of various pretreatment cliques on catalyst performance,we have also tested various preparations of Ga/ZSM-5 for the dehyogenation of ethane.\"\n          [15] \"In order to give high yields to aromatics,rhenium,platinum,or rhodium are often added to the catalysts in small amounts.\"\n          [16] \"The aims of the work presented in this paper were: (1) to obtain evidence that gallium-exchanged materials also fall into our stoichiometric theory on gallium reduction;and (2) to demonstrate that although the reduction of Ga& is necessary to disperse gallium within the zeolite, the form of the catalyst which is most active and selective for the production of aromatics does not consist of reduced Ga+ as framework cations.\"", "English": "The state of gallium and the pretreatments of gallium/ZSM-5 catalysts have significant effects on the aromatization activity. The gallium in ion-exchanged ZSM-5 can be reduced to Ga+, which is limited by the number of anionic framework sites. The reduced catalyst exhibits similar redox behavior and is as active for propane aromatization as catalysts prepared from physical mixtures of Ga203 and H-ZSM-5. However, for ethane dehydrogenation to aromatics, the reduced Ga/ZSM-5 catalysts are not as active or selective as materials that have been substantially reoxidized. Reoxidation at 550C generates a higher energy, dispersed Ga3+ which is optimal for the production of aromatics from ethane. This form of Ga3+ is stable under typical reaction conditions for ethane dehydrogenation but can be reduced by hydrogen. The role of extra-framework gallium in these materials is to enhance rates of alkene, diene, or cycloalkene dehydrogenation. High surface area Ga2O3 and steamed gallosilicates can aromatize aliphatic dienes, 1-hexene, and cyclohexene at significant rates over the temperature range 500-600C. The dispersion and oxidation state of gallium within zeolite channels greatly affect the relative rates of alkane dehydrogenation and hydrocracking. The aromatics/methane selectivity ratio is a good indicator of these relative rates. The effects of various pretreatments on catalyst performance for ethane dehydrogenation have been tested. To achieve high yields of aromatics, small amounts of rhenium, platinum, or rhodium are often added to the catalysts. The reduction of Ga2O3 is necessary to disperse gallium within the zeolite, but the most active and selective catalyst for the production of aromatics does not consist of reduced Ga+ as framework cations.", "Doi": "10.1016/0926-860x(92)80336-b"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The rate of propane dehydrocyclodimerization to form C 6 -- aromatics is limited by a sequence of irreversible dehydrogenation reactions leading to propene, higher alkenes, dienes, tfienes, and aromatics.\"\n          [2] \"Ga and Zn species increase the rates of propane chemical conversion, recombinative hydrogen desorption, and deuterium incorporation from D 2 into reaction products.\"\n          [3] \"Disposal of hydrogen formed in C-H bond activation steps occurs by transfer of H-atoms to unsaturated species to form alkanes or to Ga and Zn species, which catalyze the recombinative desorption of H-atoms to form dihydrogen (H2).\"\n          [4] \"The sequential release of several H-atoms during a propane dehydrocyclodimerization turnover limits the rate and selectivity of this reaction on H-ZSM5.\"\n          [5] \"Ga and Zn species increase the rate of H 2 formation via recombinative desorption of H-atoms formed in dehydrogenation steps.\"\n          [6] \"Ga and Zn sites allow dehydrogenation reactions to occur without the requirement for concurrent cracking.\"\n          [7] \"The addition of metal species to H-ZSM5 channels increase aromatic turnover rates and actually decrease cracking turnover rates.\"\n          [8] \"Ga and Zn species catalyze the recombinative desorption of H-atoms formed in an acid-catalyzed C-H bond activation reaction occurring as a first step in every dehydrogenation event required for an aromatization turnover.\"\n          [9] \"Ga and Zn species increase the rate of propene formation by removing H-atoms from acid sites that activate C-H bonds, allowing acid sites to turnover without the formation of cracking products.\"\n          [10] \"Ga and Zn act as 'portholes' and catalyze the recombinative desorption of H-atoms, formed from acid-catalyzed C-H bond cleavage, as all-hydrogen (He).\"", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. The rate of propane dehydrocyclodimerization to form C6 aromatics is limited by a sequence of irreversible dehydrogenation reactions leading to various unsaturated hydrocarbons and aromatics. Ga and Zn species increase the rates of propane chemical conversion, recombinative hydrogen desorption, and deuterium incorporation from D2 into reaction products. These metal species facilitate the disposal of hydrogen formed in C-H bond activation steps by catalyzing the recombinative desorption of H-atoms to form dihydrogen (H2). The sequential release of several H-atoms during a propane dehydrocyclodimerization turnover limits the rate and selectivity of this reaction on H-ZSM5. Ga and Zn species enhance the rate of H2 formation via recombinative desorption of H-atoms formed in dehydrogenation steps, allowing dehydrogenation reactions to occur without the requirement for concurrent cracking. The addition of metal species to H-ZSM5 channels increases aromatic turnover rates and decreases cracking turnover rates. These metal species act as 'portholes' for the removal of H-atoms, improving the efficiency of alkane transformations and contributing to their industrial significance. The industrial significance of metal-based catalysts in alkane transformations is attributed to their ability to enhance reaction rates and selectivities. Ga and Zn species increase the rate of propene formation by removing H-atoms from acid sites that activate C-H bonds, allowing acid sites to turnover without the formation of cracking products. This results in higher yields of desired products and reduced formation of by-products such as methane and ethane. The selective removal of H-atoms by recombinative desorption also contributes to the extraction of valuable H2 with high selectivity from light alkanes, which is highly desired in industrial processes.", "Doi": "10.1016/s0920-5861(96)00028-4"},
{"Quotes": "\"[1] \"The aim of this study was to compute intermediates and transition states involved in the catalytic cycle for the dehy- drogenation of ethane to ethene in a zinc-exchanged zeolite.\" [2] \"The results of calculations provided two distinct routes of ethane activation on the zeolite-coordinated Zn cations. The rst route starts with the alkyl activation of a CH bond (RdHd), whereas the second route starts with carbenium activation (RdHd).\" [3] \"The rst step of ethane10h13 and propane14,15 aroma- tisation in a Zn-doped zeolite catalyst is the dehydrogenation of these alkanes to the corresponding alkenes. The alkenes then undergo dehydrocyclooligomerisation.\" [4] \"The results obtained indicate that the reaction proceeds via a mechanism starting from the alkyl rupture of the ethane CH bond and the zinc cation acts as an acceptor of the alkyl group.\" [5] \"The computed activation energies for these three steps Brnsted are 18.4, 53.4 and 20.5 kcal mol1, respectively.\" [6] \"The alternative mechanism starting from the carbenium activation with the zinc cation abstracting the hydride ion, is unfavourable because of the high (C2H5dHd),activation barrier for the rst step (67.6 kcal mol1).\"", "English": "\"The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, such as zinc-exchanged zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. The study focused on the dehydrogenation of ethane to ethene in a zinc-exchanged zeolite, revealing two distinct routes of ethane activation. The first route involves the alkyl activation of a CH bond, while the second route involves carbenium activation. The dehydrogenation of alkanes to alkenes is the first step in the aromatization process in a Zn-doped zeolite catalyst, followed by dehydrocyclooligomerization. The mechanism of the reaction starts with the alkyl rupture of the ethane CH bond, with the zinc cation acting as an acceptor of the alkyl group. The computed activation energies for the three steps involved in the alkyl route are 18.4, 53.4, and 20.5 kcal mol1, respectively. The alternative mechanism starting from the carbenium activation is unfavorable due to the high activation barrier for the first step. The literature does not provide information on how the composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations, particularly in processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions, and what factors contribute to their industrial significance. The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. For instance, in Zn-exchanged zeolites, the location of metal cations in the zeolite channels and their substitution for protons play a crucial role in the catalytic activity towards alkane aromatization. The catalytic cycle for alkyl activation consists of three elementary steps: rupture of the ethane CH bond on the Zn-O pair, formation of ethene from the alkyl group bound to Zn, and formation of dihydrogen from the proton and hydrogen bound to Zn. The computed activation energies for these steps are 18.4, 53.4, and 20.5 kcal mol-1, respectively. The alternative mechanism starting from the carbenium activation is less favorable due to the high activation barrier for the first step (67.6 kcal mol-1). The industrial significance of these catalysts is due to their ability to increase the selectivity of zeolite catalysts towards aromatization of small alkanes, which is essential for the commercial Cyclar process and other aromatization processes for light hydrocarbons. The study aimed to compute intermediates and transition states involved in the catalytic cycle for the dehydrogenation of ethane to ethene in a zinc-exchanged zeolite. Two distinct routes of ethane activation on the zeolite-coordinated Zn cations were found. The first route starts with the alkyl activation of a CH bond, while the second route starts with carbenium activation. The first step of ethane and propane aromatization in a Zn-doped zeolite catalyst is the dehydrogenation of these alkanes to the corresponding alkenes, followed by dehydrocyclooligomerization. The reaction proceeds via a mechanism starting from the alkyl rupture of the ethane CH bond, with the zinc cation acting as an acceptor of the alkyl group. The computed activation energies for the three steps are 18.4, 53.4, and 20.5 kcal mol1, respectively. The alternative mechanism starting from the carbenium activation with the zinc cation abstracting the hydride ion is unfavorable due to the high activation barrier for the first step.\"", "Doi": "10.1039/a909426a"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The catalytic conversion of methane to more valu- able liquid fuels is still a challenging problem in the eld of catalysis [13].\"\n          [2] \"Among the different routes proposed during the previous years, the direct partial oxidation of methane to C1 oxygenates, formaldehyde or methanol, has been one of the most studied since it could potentially substitute the conventional three step' industrial process.\"\n          [3] \"The nature and the dispersion of the metal oxide phase have a great inuence on the catalysts behavior.\"\n          [4] \"Banares et al. [13], reported selectivities above 90% at methane conversion of 0.6% using a MoO3/SiO2 catalyst.\"\n          [5] \"It has been demonstrated that the nature and the dispersion of the metal oxide phase have a great inuence on the catalysts behavior.\"\n          [6] \"Banares et al. [13,14] and Faraldos et al. [15] have reported that methane conversion and formaldehyde selectivity are dependent on metal loading and the dispersion of the surface species.\"\n          [7] \"In this paper, we report the results obtained in the partial oxidation of methane to formaldehyde over W/HZSM-5 catalysts using molecular oxygen as oxidant.\"\n          [8] \"Formaldehyde selectivity seems to be related to the dispersion of the tungsten oxide phase, which, in turn, is inuenced by the metal loading.\"", "English": "The catalytic conversion of methane to more valuable liquid fuels is a significant challenge in the field of catalysis. Direct partial oxidation of methane to C1 oxygenates, such as formaldehyde or methanol, is a widely studied route that could potentially replace the conventional three-step industrial process. The nature and dispersion of the metal oxide phase have a significant impact on the behavior of catalysts. Banares et al. reported formaldehyde selectivities above 90% at a methane conversion of 0.6% using a MoO3/SiO2 catalyst. It has been demonstrated that the nature and dispersion of the metal oxide phase greatly influence the behavior of catalysts. Banares et al. and Faraldos et al. have reported that methane conversion and formaldehyde selectivity are dependent on metal loading and the dispersion of surface species. This paper reports the results of the partial oxidation of methane to formaldehyde over W/HZSM-5 catalysts using molecular oxygen as an oxidant. Formaldehyde selectivity appears to be related to the dispersion of the tungsten oxide phase, which is influenced by metal loading.", "Doi": "10.1016/s0926-860x(98)00114-8"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The catalysts and reaction conditions are presented. Emphasis has been focused on the modification of catalysts and optimization of reaction conditions.\"\n          [2] \"The results of investigations on the interactions between Mo and/or transition metal ions and the zeolite support, as well as, the reaction mechanisms of the formation of aromatics and carbonaceous deposits are discussed.\"\n          [3] \"The channel structure and acidity of the reactivity and/or stability of the catalysts, while the addition of V, Li, and P has the opposite influence.\"\n          [5] \"In addition, the preparation method, the consequence of impregnation of the metal components, and the calcined temperature, etc. can also affect the performance.\"\n          [6] \"Various pre-treatments and different reaction conditions, such as pre-treatment atmosphere and temperature, reaction temperature, pressure, methane space velocity, and regeneration, exerted great influences on the catalytic performance.\"\n          [7] \"The interaction between addition of the second metal component changed the acid sites of the zeolite, decreasing the amount of strong acid sites and increasing that of moderate strength acid sites.\"\n          [9] \"The mode of methane activation continues to be the focus of debate in the literature and many kinds of active sites and reaction mechanisms have been proposed.\"\n          [10] \"The heavy carbonaceous
