Catalytic dehydro- genation of ethane over the Ga2O2 proceeds via initial heterolytic dissociation by the Lewis acidbase pair formed by the Ga3+ and the basic extraframework oxygen atom followed by olefin desorption and hydrogen recombination.\"\n          [5] \"The decreased basicity of the extraframework oxygen and the stable tetrahedral coordination of Ga3+ in the dimeric species facilitate H2 desorption. However, hydrogenation of the cluster in principle opens a pathway to its decomposition via water desorption, resulting in less reactive reduced sites.\"\n          [6] \"Such insight predicts that addition of water to the hydrocarbon feed increases the steady-state concentration of the reactive oxygenated extraframework species.\"\n          [7] \"Catalytic experiments support well this proposal: a substantial increase in the dehydrogenation activity of Ga+/ZSM-5 zeolite is observed upon water co-feeding.\"", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, such as supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. Spectroscopy elucidates the structure-activity relationship, crucial for understanding and optimizing catalytic performance. For metal-exchanged zeolites, the reactivity in confined spaces is studied through the interplay between spectroscopy and theory, leading to the development of structure-activity relationships for catalysis. The stability and reactivity of extraframework metal-containing cationic species in high-silica zeolites are governed by factors such as the coordination environment and the necessity to compensate for positive extraframework charges. The formation of multinuclear oxygenated gallium species with optimal coordination of metal centers is a driving force for oligomerization of isolated mononuclear GaO+ species in microporous space. Binuclear gallium-oxo cationic species exhibit significant reactivity toward heterolytic CH cleavage, facilitating catalytic dehydrogenation of ethane. The decreased basicity of extraframework oxygen and stable tetrahedral coordination of Ga3+ in dimeric species promote H2 desorption. However, hydrogenation of the cluster can lead to its decomposition via water desorption, resulting in less reactive reduced sites. The addition of water to the hydrocarbon feed increases the steady-state concentration of reactive oxygenated extraframework species, as supported by catalytic experiments showing a substantial increase in dehydrogenation activity of Ga+/ZSM-5 zeolite upon water co-feeding. These factors contribute to the industrial significance of metal-based catalysts in alkane transformations, particularly in processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions.", "Doi": "10.1039/b815943b"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"Supported vanadium oxide catalysts, containing surface vanadia species on oxide supports, are extensively employed as catalysts for many hydrocarbon oxidation reactions.\"\n          [2] \"This paper discusses the current fundamental information available about the structure and reactivity of surface vanadia species on oxide supports: monolayer surface coverage, stability of the surface vanadia monolayer,oxidation state of the surface vanadia species, molecular structures of the surface vanadia species (as a function of environment and catalyst composition), acidity of the surface vanadia species and reactivity of the surface vanadia species.\"\n          [3] \"Comparison of the molecular structure and reactivity information provides new fundamental insights into the catalytic properties of surface vanadia species during hydrocarbon oxidation reactions: (1) the role of terminal V=O, bridging V-O-V and bridging V-O-support bonds, (2) the number of surface vanadia sites required, (3) the influence of metal oxide additives, (4) the influence of surface acidic and basic sites, (5) the influence of preparation methods and (6) the influence of the specific oxide support phase.\"\n          [4] \"The unique physical and chemical characteristics of supported vanadia catalysts, compared to other supported metal oxide catalysts, for hydrocarbon oxidation reactions are also discussed.\"\n          [5] \"The surface vanadia monolayer is stable after its initial formation on many typical oxide supports (A1203, TiO2, ZrO2, Nb205 and CeO2).\"\n          [6] \"The surface vanadia monolayer on oxide supports is also stable under reducing and reaction environ- ments.\"\n          [7] \"The stability of the surface vanadia monolayers is reflected in the long life of such industrial oxidation catalysts.\"\n          [8] \"The molecular structures of the surface vanadia species have been extensively investigated in the past few years with many different spectroscopies.\"\n          [9] \"The molecular structures of these surface vanadia species are tentatively thought to consist of a terminal V=O bond and three bridging V-O-support bonds for the isolated species, and a terminal V=O bond with one bridging V-O-support and two bridging V-O-V bonds for the polymerized species.\"\n          [10] \"The molecular structures of the surface vanadia species are determined by the net pH of the aqueous thin film, which depends on the surface point of zero charge of the oxide support and the amount of the surface vanadia species.\"\n          [11] \"The hydration-dehydration processes of the supported vanadia catalysts are completely reversible.\"\n          [12] \"Exposure of the surface vanadia (5+) species to reducing H2 and CO environ- ments results in the formation of surface vanadia (4+) and vanadia (3+) species.\"\n          [13] \"Direct information about the molecular structures of the reduced surface vanadia species can be obtained from in situ EPR for isolated V(4+) [2,47,57], and UV- VIS DRS measurements for V(4+,3+) [47,56,57] and XANES/EXAFS for V(4+,3) (no known studies at this point).\"\n          [14] \"The influence of hydrocarbon oxidation reaction environments upon the oxida- tion states of the surface vanadia species in supported vanadia catalysts has been examined for several reactions with in situ Raman spectroscopy.\"\n          [15] \"The in situ Raman studies provide new insights into the behavior of surface vanadia species during hydrocarbon oxidation reactions: (1) the dehydrated V(5) surface vanadia species appears to be the predominant surface vanadia species, (2) the extent of reduction of the surface vanadia species depends on the reducing power of the hydrocarbon (methanol> butene>butane>methane), (3) the specific oxide support and (4) the ratio of polymerized to isolated surface vanadia species (polymerized>isolated).\"\n          [16] \"The greater stability of the V(5) silica supported vanadia species may be directly related to the fact that only isolated surface vanadia species are present in this catalyst.\"\n          [17] \"The influence of preparation methods upon the molecular structure of the hydrated and dehydrated surface vanadia species has also been examined.\"\n          [18] \"The same thermodynamically stable surface metal oxide species are formed independent of the specific synthesis method.\"\n          [19] \"The influence of the specific structure or modification of the oxide support upon the molecular structure of the dehydrated surface vanadia species on well-defined TiO2 supports (anatase, rutile, brookite and B) was investigated with solid state 51V NMR and Raman spectroscopy.\"\n          [20] \"The same dehydrated surface vanadia species, already discussed above in Section 5.1.2, were found to be present on all the different TiO2 modifications suggesting that there is no effect of long range order of the oxide substrate upon the local structure of the surface vanadia species.\"\n          [21] \"The oxide supports only possess surface Lewis acid sites and the relative strength of these sites is A12Oa>Nb2Os>TiO2>ZrO2, and no surface Lewis acid sites are detected for SiO2.\"\n          [22] \"In contrast to the oxide supports, unsupported V205 crystalline powders possess both surface BrCnsted and surface Lewis acid sites.\"\n          [23] \"The formation of the surface vanadia species on the oxide supports is accompanied by a decrease in the number of surface Lewis acid sites and an increase in the number of surface Br0nsted acid sites.\"\n          [24] \"The exact location of the surface BrCnsted acid sites is not clear at present since solid state 1H NMR studies cannot clearly discriminate between different locations due to similar NMR peak positions.\"\n          [25] \"The acidic characteristics of the surface vanadia overlayer are influenced by the specific oxide support ligand, but the molecular structural characterization studies above (see Section 3) reveal that the same dehydrated surface vanadia species are present on all the oxide supports (with the exception of silica).\"\n          [26] \"The in situ characterization studies (Section 5.5) revealed that dehydrated surface vanadia species are present during hydrocarbon oxidation reactions and, consequently, the reactivity properties need to be related to the dehydrated surface vanadia species.\"\n          [27] \"The reactivity properties of the supported vanadia catalysts will be compared with the structural properties of the dehydrated surface V(5+) species rather than the dehydrated, reduced surface vanadia V(4+) and V(3+) species.\"\n          [28] \"The terminal V=O bonds have been proposed by many investigators to contain the critical oxygen involved in hydrocarbon oxidation reactions over supported vanadia catalysts [4].\"\n          [29] \"The available data suggests that the terminal V=O bonds do not contain the critical oxygen that affects the reactivity of supported vanadia catalysts during hydrocarbon oxidation reactions.\"\n          [30] \"The surface concentration of bridging V-O-V bonds increases with surface vanadia coverage due to the increase in the ratio of polymerized to isolated surface vanadia species with the exception of V205]SiO 2 (see Section 5.1 above).\"\n          [31] \"Although the bridging V-O-V bonds do not appear to significantly influence many of the oxidation reactions, more systematic studies with well-defined model supported vanadia catalysts are required to fully understand the role of bridging V-O-V bonds in hydrocarbon oxidation reactions.\"\n          [32] \"The bridging V-O-support bond appears to be associated with the critical oxygen required for hydrocarbon oxidation reactions since changing the specific oxide support dra- matically affects the TOF: approximately four orders of magnitude for methanol oxidation to formaldehyde [19] and two-orders of magnitude for butane oxidation to maleic anhydride [36].\"\n          [33] \"The general trend appears to be CeOz>ZrO2 TiO2>NbzOs>A12Os>SiO2, which inversely correlates with the Sanderson elec- tronegativity of the oxide support cations [97].\"\n          [34] \"This suggests that bridging oxygens in V-O-support bonds that are more electronegative or basic, corresponding to oxide support cations with a lower electronegativity,are associated with the critical oxygen required for hydrocarbon oxidation reactions over supported vanadia catalysts.\"\n          [35] \"In general, reactions requiring only one surface site will exhibit a TOF that is independent of surface vanadia coverage.\"\n          [36] \"The invariance of the TOF for methanol oxidation to formaldehyde with surface vanadia coverage over supported vanadia catalysts suggests that only one surface vanadia site is required for this reaction.\"\n          [37] \"The oxidation of methane to formaldehyde over V205/ SiO2 catalysts also exhibits a constant TOF with surface vanadia coverage suggesting that only one surface vanadia site is involved with this reaction, and is consistent with the isolated nature of the surface vanadia species on silica [35].\"\n          [38] \"An increase in the TOF with the surface vanadia coverage may reflect the requirement of multiple surface vanadia sites or the influence of other factors (e.g., surface acidity,influence of bridging V-O-V bonds, structural changes, etc.).\"\n          [39] \"Some of these other factors can be discriminated with the addition of metal oxide additives to the supported vanadia catalysts as discussed below.\"\n          [40] \"The addition of surface niobia is especially informative since it has a minimal effect on the surface vanadia structure, see Section 5.6 above, and its presence primarily increases the number of adjacent surface metal oxide sites for the surface vanadia species.\"\n          [41] \"The introduction of surface niobia species to V2Os/TiO2 catalysts increases the TOF for the oxidation of butane to maleic anhydride [36].\"\n          [42] \"This increase in TOF reflects the requirement of multiple surface metal oxide sites for this hydrocarbon oxidation reaction.\"\n          [43] \"Interacting additives and especially interacting basic surface oxides retard the reduction of surface vanadia species.\"\n          [44] \"Consequently, the TOFs for all hydrocarbon oxidation reactions are decreased when basic additives are intro- duced.\"\n          [45] \"The negative effect of the basic additives on the TOFs for methanol oxidation and propane oxidation over V2Os/TiO2 catalysts have been reported in the literature [59,99].\"\n          [46] \"In the case of V205/SIO2, the situation is even more drastic since the basic metal oxide additives also convert the two-dimensional surface vanadia species to three-dimensional crystalline mixed metal oxide phases [100].\"\n          [47] \"Interacting acidic additives such as P may have a different effect on various oxidation reactions.\"\n          [48] \"For methanol oxidation to formaldehyde, the presence of surface phosphate species slightly decreases the TOF [59].\"\n          [49] \"However, for butane oxidation to maleic anhydride the presence of surface phosphate species increases the TOF [36].\"\n          [50] \"The surface niobia species, a noninteracting additive possessing Lewis acidity [75], has no effect on the selectivity of formaldehyde during methanol oxidation [59], but does have a positive effect on the maleic anhydride selectivity during butane oxidation [36].\"\n          [51] \"The formaldehyde selectivity during methanol oxidation is slightly enhanced by the presence of basic interacting additives and decreased by the presence of acidic interacting additives [59].\"\n          [52] \"The propylene selectivity during propane oxidative dehydrogenation is enhanced by the presence of basic interacting additives [99].\"\n          [53] \"In contrast, the maleic anhydride selectivity during butane oxidation is enhanced by the presence of acidic interacting additives [36].\"\n          [54] \"It is tempting to conclude from this limited data that the selectivity of oxidative dehydrogenation reactions, oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde and propane to propylene, is enhanced by basic additives and that the selectivity of hydrogen abstraction-oxygen insertion reactions, butane oxidation to maleic anhydride, is enhanced by acidic additives.\"\n          [55] \"However, many more hydrocarbon oxidation reactions need to be examined before these observations can be general- ized.\"\n          [56] \"The specific phase of the oxide support as well as the specific preparation method do not appear to influence the molecular structure or reac- tivity of the surface vanadia species.\"\n          [57] \"The number of surface vanadia sites required for a hydrocarbon oxidation reaction is dependent on the specific reac- tant molecule.\"\n          [58] \"Oxidation reactions requiring only one surface vanadia sites are generally not sensitive to the surface vanadia coverage and the presence of noninteracting metal oxide additives.\"\n          [59] \"Oxidation reactions requiring multiple surface vanadia sites are very sensitive to surface vanadia coverage and the presence of noninteracting metal oxide additives.\"\n          [60] \"However, interacting additives influence all hydrocarbon oxidation reactions since they modify the surface vanadia sites.\"\n          [61] \"Acidic and basic additives also influence the selectivity of hydro- carbon oxidation reactions, but the effect appears to be reaction specific and cannot be generalized with the limited data currently available.\"", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations, particularly in processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions. Supported vanadium oxide catalysts, which contain surface vanadia species on oxide supports, are widely used in hydrocarbon oxidation reactions. The structure and reactivity of these surface vanadia species are influenced by factors such as monolayer surface coverage, stability of the surface vanadia monolayer, oxidation state, molecular structures, acidity, and the specific oxide support phase. The stability of the surface vanadia monolayer on typical oxide supports ensures the long life of industrial oxidation catalysts. The molecular structures of the surface vanadia species have been extensively studied using various spectroscopic techniques. The molecular structures of the surface vanadia species are determined by the net pH of the aqueous thin film, which depends on the surface point of zero charge of the oxide support and the amount of the surface vanadia species. The hydration-dehydration processes of the supported vanadia catalysts are completely reversible. The reduction of surface vanadia species in reducing environments results in the formation of surface vanadia (4+) and vanadia (3+) species. The molecular structures of the reduced surface vanadia species can be determined using in situ EPR, UV-VIS DRS, and XANES/EXAFS measurements. The influence of hydrocarbon oxidation reaction environments on the oxidation states of the surface vanadia species in supported vanadia catalysts has been examined for several reactions using in situ Raman spectroscopy. The in situ Raman studies provide insights into the behavior of surface vanadia species during hydrocarbon oxidation reactions, including the predominant surface vanadia species, the extent of reduction, the specific oxide support, and the ratio of polymerized to isolated surface vanadia species. The stability of the V(5) silica supported vanadia species may be related to the presence of only isolated surface vanadia species in this catalyst. The influence of preparation methods on the molecular structure of the hydrated and dehydrated surface vanadia species has been examined, and the same thermodynamically stable surface metal oxide species are formed independent of the specific synthesis method. The influence of the specific structure or modification of the oxide support on the molecular structure of the dehydrated surface vanadia species has been investigated, and no effect of long range order of the oxide substrate on the local structure of the surface vanadia species was found. The oxide supports possess surface Lewis acid sites, while unsupported V205 crystalline powders possess both surface BrCnsted and surface Lewis acid sites. The formation of the surface vanadia species on the oxide supports is accompanied by a decrease in the number of surface Lewis acid sites and an increase in the number of surface Br0nsted acid sites. The exact location of the surface BrCnsted acid sites is unclear, and the acidic characteristics of the surface vanadia overlayer are influenced by the specific oxide support ligand. The reactivity properties of supported vanadia catalysts are related to the dehydrated surface vanadia species, and the reactivity properties will be compared with the structural properties of the dehydrated surface V(5+) species rather than the dehydrated, reduced surface vanadia V(4+) and V(3+) species. The terminal V=O bonds do not contain the critical oxygen that affects the reactivity of supported vanadia catalysts during hydrocarbon oxidation reactions. The surface concentration of bridging V-O-V bonds increases with surface vanadia coverage, and more systematic studies are required to fully understand the role of bridging V-O-V bonds in hydrocarbon oxidation reactions. The bridging V-O-support bond appears to be associated with the critical oxygen required for hydrocarbon oxidation reactions, and changing the specific oxide support dramatically affects the TOF. The general trend is inversely correlated with the Sanderson electronegativity of the oxide support cations, suggesting that bridging oxygens in V-O-support bonds that are more electronegative or basic are associated with the critical oxygen required for hydrocarbon oxidation reactions over supported vanadia catalysts. The number of surface vanadia sites required for a hydrocarbon oxidation reaction is dependent on the specific reactant molecule. Oxidation reactions requiring only one surface vanadia site exhibit a TOF that is independent of surface vanadia coverage, while oxidation reactions requiring multiple surface vanadia sites are sensitive to surface vanadia coverage and the presence of noninteracting metal oxide additives. Interacting additives influence all hydrocarbon oxidation reactions by modifying the surface vanadia sites. Acidic and basic additives also influence the selectivity of hydrocarbon oxidation reactions, but the effect appears to be reaction-specific and cannot be generalized with the limited data currently available. The unique physical and chemical characteristics of supported vanadia catalysts, compared to other supported metal oxide catalysts, contribute to their industrial significance in hydrocarbon oxidation reactions.", "Doi": "10.1016/s0926-860x(97)00021-5"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. In processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions, the nature of the active sites, the acidity, and the pore structure of the catalysts play crucial roles. The industrial significance of these catalysts is attributed to their ability to activate and transform light alkanes into more valuable products, such as aromatics and isomers, under mild conditions. The efficiency of these transformations is enhanced by optimizing the catalyst composition and reaction conditions, which can lead to higher yields and selectivities. Moreover, the development of novel regeneration methods for these catalysts can help to mitigate deactivation and extend their operational life, further enhancing their industrial application.", "Doi": "10.1016/j.molcata.2006.03.068"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The catalytic properties of Al2O3-supported vanadia with a wide range of VOx surface density (1.434.2 V/nm2) and structure were examined for the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane and propane.\"\n          [2] \"Propene formation rates (per V atom) are approximately eight times higher than ethene formation rates at a given reaction temperature, but the apparent ODH activation energies (E1) are similar for the two reactants and relatively insensitive to vanadia surface density.\"\n          [3] \"The ratio of k2/k1 is independent of surface density for ethane but increases slightly with vanadia surface density for propane, suggesting that isolated structures prevalent at low surface densities are slightly more selective for alkane dehydrogenation reactions.\"\n          [4] \"The ratio of k3/k1 decreases markedly with increasing reaction temperature for both ethane and propane ODH.\"\n          [5] \"The highest yield of alkene is obtained for catalysts containing predominantly isolated monovanadate species and operated at high temperatures that avoid homogeneous reactions (<800 K).\"\n          [6] \"The effects of oxide domain size and of support on rates and selectivity have been attributed to the acidbase properties of the VOx and support surfaces.\"\n          [7] \"The effects of VOx surface density and structure on rates and selectivities for ethane and propane ODH reactions have been previously reported (718), with somewhat inconsistent results.\"\n          [8] \"The lack of detailed structural characterization and rigorous kinetic analysis of integral (high conversion) rate and selectivity data, and the temperature gradients and possible homogeneous reactions prevalent at the high temperatures and conversions of many previous studies, have contributed to the persistent controversies.\"\n          [9] \"Here, we report a detailed kinetic analysis of ethane ODH reactions on VOx/Al2O3 samples with a wide range of VOx surface densities (1.434 VOx/nm2) and contrast the results with those obtained using propane as the reactant.\"\n          [10] \"We have combined this analysis with detailed structural characterization of these catalysts in order to relate their local structure to the values of the rate constants,which characterize the function of these catalytic materials.\"\n          [11] \"In addition, we contrast the reaction rates of ethane and propane molecules with different CH bond energies and different adsorption energies of the respective alkenes.\"\n          [12] \"As surface densities increase, (per V atom) are strongly influenced by vanadia surface density and reach a maximum value at intermediate surface densities (8 V/nm2).\"\n          [14] \"The effects of oxide domain size and of support on rates and selectivity have been attributed to the acidbase properties of the VOx and support surfaces.\"\n          [15] \"The local structure of supported VOx domains strongly influences ODH reaction rates and selectivity.\"\n          [16] \"High alkene yields at reasonable residence times require high values of k1 and low values of k2/k1 and k3/k1.\"\n          [17] \"The effects of VOx surface density and structure on rates and selectivities for ethane and propane ODH reactions have been previously reported (718), with somewhat inconsistent results.\"\n          [18] \"The lack of detailed structural characterization and rigorous kinetic analysis of integral (high conversion) rate and selectivity data, and the temperature gradients and possible homogeneous reactions prevalent at the high temperatures and conversions of many previous studies, have contributed to the persistent controversies.\"\n          [19] \"The spectroscopic results presented in Figs. 1 and 2 suggest that distorted tetrahedral monovanadate structures connected to the support via VOAl bonds are prevalent at low surface densities.\"\n          [20] \"As V surface densities increase, two-dimensional polyvanadates form via reactions leading to VOV bonds connecting neighboring VOx species.\"\n          [21] \"VOx species exceeding monolayer coverages react with polyvanadates structures to form three-dimensional structures that ultimately crystallize into bulk V2O5, with some evidence for residual monovanadate species.\"\n          [22] \"The rate per V atom increases with surface densities, even though V atoms become increasingly unavailable for catalysis as three-dimensional structures form.\"\n          [23] \"The constant areal rate obtained after completion of a polyvanadate monolayer suggests that the surface reactivity of VOx species becomes independent of domain size once the predominant structures involve VOV bonds.\"\n          [24] \"The sample with the lowest vanadia surface density (1.4 V/nm2) and containing predominately monovanadates shows the highest initial alkene selectivity for both ethane and propane ODH.\"\n          [25] \"The ratio of k2/k1 is independent of surface density for ethane and increases with increasing vanadia surface density for propane (Fig. 8).\"\n          [26] \"The ratio of k3/k1 increases with increasing vanadia surface density for both reactants (Fig. 10).\"\n          [27] \"Smaller values of k3/k1 and k2/k1 lead to higher alkene selectivity at all reactant conversion levels.\"\n          [28] \"The ratio of k2/k1 is relatively independent of both reaction temperature and vanadia surface density for ethane ODH.\"\n          [29] \"The ratio of k2/k1 is independent of reaction temperature, but increases with increasing vanadia surface density for propane ODH.\"\n          [30] \"However, k3/k1 is generally higher for propane than for ethane ODH, indicating that the propene is more reactive relative to propane than ethene is to ethane.\"\n          [31] \"The activation energies for ethane and propane ODH, E1, and ethane and propane combustion, E2, are similar in magnitude at 115  20 kJ/mol and show weak dependence on vanadia surface density.\"\n          [32] \"The propene formation rate is approximately eight times larger than the ethene formation rate at 663 K, suggesting that that the stabilization energy for ethoxide species may be higher relative to isopropoxide in the activated state.\"\n          [33] \"The apparent activation energy for alkene combustion, E3, is 6090 kJ/mol and increases with vanadia surface density, leading to a decrease in E13 with increasing vanadia surface density.\"\n          [34] \"The trends in E3 and E13 appear to be caused by decreasingly exothermic alkene adsorption as vanadia surface density increases.\"\n          [35] \"Alkene selectivity generally increases with increasing reaction temperature and with decreasing vanadia surface density.\"\n          [36] \"Therefore, the highest olefin yields are obtained on catalysts containing isolated monovanadates and operated at the highest possible reaction temperature consistent with the avoidance of homogeneous reactions.\"\n          [37] \"As surface densities increase, two-dimensional poly-vanadates appear (2.37.0 V/nm2), along with increasing amounts of V2O5 crystallites at surface densities (8 V/nm2).\"\n          [39] \"The highest yield of alkene is obtained for catalysts containing predominantly isolated monovanadate species and operated at high temperatures that avoid homogeneous reactions (<800 K).\"\n          [40] \"The effects of oxide domain size and of support on rates and selectivity have been attributed to the acidbase properties of the VOx and support surfaces.\"\n          [41] \"The local structure of supported VOx domains strongly influences ODH reaction rates and selectivity.\"\n          [42] \"High alkene yields at reasonable residence times require high values of k1 and low values of k2/k1 and k3/k1.\"\n          [43] \"The effects of VOx surface density and structure on rates and selectivities for ethane and propane ODH reactions have been previously reported (718), with somewhat inconsistent results.\"\n          [44] \"The lack of detailed structural characterization and rigorous kinetic analysis of integral (high conversion) rate and selectivity data, and the temperature gradients and possible homogeneous reactions prevalent at the high temperatures and conversions of many previous studies, have contributed to the persistent controversies.\"\n          [45] \"Here, we report a detailed kinetic analysis of ethane ODH reactions on VOx/Al2O3 samples with a wide range of VOx surface densities (1.434 VOx/nm2) and contrast the results with those obtained using propane as the reactant.\"\n          [46] \"We have combined this analysis with detailed structural characterization of these catalysts in order to relate their local structure to the values of the rate constants,which characterize the function of these catalytic materials.\"\n          [47] \"In addition, we contrast the reaction rates of ethane and propane molecules with different CH bond energies and different adsorption energies of the respective alkenes.\"", "English": "The catalytic properties of alumina-supported vanadia with a wide range of vanadia surface densities and structures were examined for the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane and propane. Propene formation rates are about eight times higher than ethene formation rates at a given reaction temperature, but the apparent activation energies for oxidative dehydrogenation are similar for both reactants and relatively insensitive to vanadia surface density. The ratio of the rate constant for alkane combustion to the rate constant for oxidative dehydrogenation is independent of surface density for ethane but increases slightly with vanadia surface density for propane. The ratio of the rate constant for alkene combustion to the rate constant for oxidative dehydrogenation decreases markedly with increasing reaction temperature for both ethane and propane oxidative dehydrogenation. The highest yield of alkene is obtained for catalysts containing predominantly isolated monovanadate species and operated at high temperatures that avoid homogeneous reactions. The effects of oxide domain size and support on rates and selectivity have been attributed to the acid-base properties of the vanadia and support surfaces. Previous studies on the effects of vanadia surface density and structure on rates and selectivities for ethane and propane oxidative dehydrogenation have yielded inconsistent results. The lack of detailed structural characterization and rigorous kinetic analysis, as well as the temperature gradients and possible homogeneous reactions prevalent at high temperatures and conversions in many previous studies, have contributed to the persistent controversies. A detailed kinetic analysis of ethane oxidative dehydrogenation reactions on vanadia/alumina samples with a wide range of vanadia surface densities was reported, contrasting the results with those obtained using propane as the reactant. This analysis was combined with detailed structural characterization of the catalysts to relate their local structure to the values of the rate constants that characterize the function of these catalytic materials. The reaction rates of ethane and propane molecules with different CH bond energies and different adsorption energies of the respective alkenes were also contrasted. As the surface density increases, two-dimensional poly-vanadates appear, along with increasing amounts of V2O5 crystallites. Ethene and propene formation rates per vanadium atom are strongly influenced by vanadia surface density, reaching a maximum at intermediate surface densities. The highest yield of alkene is obtained for catalysts containing predominantly isolated monovanadate species and operated at high temperatures that avoid homogeneous reactions. The effects of oxide domain size and support on rates and selectivity have been attributed to the acid-base properties of the vanadia and support surfaces. The local structure of supported vanadia domains strongly influences oxidative dehydrogenation reaction rates and selectivity. High alkene yields at reasonable residence times require high values of k1 and low values of k2/k1 and k3/k1. The effects of vanadia surface density and structure on ethane and propane oxidative dehydrogenation rates and selectivities have been previously reported with inconsistent results. The lack of detailed structural characterization and rigorous kinetic analysis, as well as the temperature gradients and possible homogeneous reactions at high temperatures and conversions in many previous studies, have contributed to ongoing controversies. The spectroscopic results suggest that distorted tetrahedral monovanadate structures connected to the support via VOAl bonds are prevalent at low surface densities. As V surface densities increase, two-dimensional polyvanadates form via reactions leading to VOV bonds connecting neighboring VOx species. VOx species exceeding monolayer coverages react with polyvanadates structures to form three-dimensional structures that ultimately crystallize into bulk V2O5, with some evidence for residual monovanadate species. The rate per V atom increases with surface densities, even though V atoms become increasingly unavailable for catalysis as three-dimensional structures form. The constant areal rate obtained after completion of a polyvanadate monolayer suggests that the surface reactivity of VOx species becomes independent of domain size once the predominant structures involve VOV bonds. The sample with the lowest vanadia surface density and containing predominately monovanadates shows the highest initial alkene selectivity for both ethane and propane ODH. The ratio of k2/k1 is independent of surface density for ethane and increases with increasing vanadia surface density for propane. The ratio of k3/k1 increases with increasing vanadia surface density for both reactants. Smaller values of k3/k1 and k2/k1 lead to higher alkene selectivity at all reactant conversion levels. The ratio of k2/k1 is relatively independent of both reaction temperature and vanadia surface density for ethane ODH. The ratio of k2/k1 is independent of reaction temperature, but increases with increasing vanadia surface density for propane ODH. However, k3/k1 is generally higher for propane than for ethane ODH, indicating that the propene is more reactive relative to propane than ethene is to ethane. The activation energies for ethane and propane ODH, E1, and ethane and propane combustion, E2, are similar in magnitude at 115  20 kJ/mol and show weak dependence on vanadia surface density. The propene formation rate is approximately eight times larger than the ethene formation rate at 663 K, suggesting that that the stabilization energy for ethoxide species may be higher relative to isopropoxide in the activated state. The apparent activation energy for alkene combustion, E3, is 6090 kJ/mol and increases with vanadia surface density, leading to a decrease in E13 with increasing vanadia surface density. The trends in E3 and E13 appear to be caused by decreasingly exothermic alkene adsorption as vanadia surface density increases. Alkene selectivity generally increases with increasing reaction temperature and with decreasing vanadia surface density. Therefore, the highest olefin yields are obtained on catalysts containing isolated monovanadates and operated at the highest possible reaction temperature consistent with the avoidance of homogeneous reactions. As surface densities increase, two-dimensional poly-vanadates appear, along with increasing amounts of V2O5 crystallites. Ethene and propene formation rates (per V atom) are strongly influenced by vanadia surface density and reach a maximum value at intermediate surface densities. The highest yield of alkene is obtained for catalysts containing predominantly isolated monovanadate species and operated at high temperatures that avoid homogeneous reactions. The effects of oxide domain size and of support on rates and selectivity have been attributed to the acidbase properties of the VOx and support surfaces. The local structure of supported VOx domains strongly influences ODH reaction rates and selectivity. High alkene yields at reasonable residence times require high values of k1 and low values of k2/k1 and k3/k1. The effects of VOx surface density and structure on rates and selectivities for ethane and propane ODH reactions have been previously reported, with somewhat inconsistent results. The lack of detailed structural characterization and rigorous kinetic analysis of integral (high conversion) rate and selectivity data, and the temperature gradients and possible homogeneous reactions prevalent at the high temperatures and conversions of many previous studies, have contributed to the persistent controversies. A detailed kinetic analysis of ethane ODH reactions on VOx/Al2O3 samples with a wide range of VOx surface densities was reported and contrasted with those obtained using propane as the reactant. This analysis was combined with detailed structural characterization of these catalysts in order to relate their local structure to the values of the rate constants. In addition, the reaction rates of ethane and propane molecules with different CH bond energies and different adsorption energies of the respective alkenes were contrasted.", "Doi": "10.1006/jcat.2002.3570"},
{"Quotes": "\"Catalytic reactions of hydrocarbons in zeolites can be profoundly affected by extraframework transition-metal cationic clusters. MFI zeolites containing dehydrogenating species such as gallium, zinc, and platinum form the basis for light alkane aromatization (Cyclar, Aroforming, Z-forming) processes.\"\n          \"An additional appealing example is the incorporation of methane into gasoline products in the MTG process over Ga/HZSM-5.\"\n          \"A catalytic issue relates to the nature of the cationic clusters. Are the alkanes activated by isolated cations, or do the extraframework oxygen atoms also play a role?\"\n          \"The experimentally observed increase in activity of Ga+ species in ZSM-5 upon oxidation at 473K by nitrous oxide was ascribed to formation of gallyl (GaO+) ions.\"\n          \"According to this reaction scheme, GaO+ can be stabilized by addition of steam.\"\n          \"The increased dehydrogenation activity of Ga/ZSM-5 compared to HZSM-5 is obvious from the increased amount of hydrogen formed.\"\n          \"The promoting effect of water is due to the formation of reactive partly hydrolyzed gallium species.\"\n          \"Coordination of the hydroxyl group of the [Ga(H)(OH)]+ ion to the neighboring gallium cation results in a significant decrease of the reaction energy for H2 recombination (147kJmol1) compared to that from the isolated [Ga(H)(OH)]+ ion (242kJmol1).\"\n          \"The increased acidity of the bridging hydroxyl bond and the stable tetrahedral configuration around Ga3+ ions facilitate H2 desorption.\"\n          \"Dehydrogenation of an alkane over the Ga2O2 dimer proceeds by initial heterolytic dissociation by the Lewis acid pair formed by Ga3+ and the basic extraframework oxygen atom (Scheme1) with subsequent olefin desorption and hydrogen recombination.\"", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, such as gallium, zinc, and platinum in MFI zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. These catalysts are crucial for processes like light alkane aromatization and the incorporation of methane into gasoline products. The nature of the cationic clusters, whether isolated cations or involving extraframework oxygen atoms, plays a key role in alkane activation. Oxidation of Ga+ species in ZSM-5 by nitrous oxide leads to the formation of gallyl (GaO+) ions, which are more reactive. The addition of steam stabilizes GaO+ ions, enhancing the dehydrogenation activity of Ga/ZSM-5 compared to HZSM-5. Water promotes the formation of reactive hydrolyzed gallium species, decreasing the reaction energy for hydrogen recombination. The stable tetrahedral configuration around Ga3+ ions facilitates hydrogen desorption. Alkane dehydrogenation over the Ga2O2 dimer involves heterolytic dissociation by the Lewis acid pair formed by Ga3+ and the basic extraframework oxygen atom, followed by olefin desorption and hydrogen recombination.", "Doi": "10.1002/anie.200702463"},

{"Quotes": "[1] \"Two Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst series have been tested in the partial oxidation of methane to formaldehyde at atmospheric pres- sure.\"\n          [2] \"Conventional aqueous impregnation with ammonium heptamolybdate was used for preparing catalysts with Mo loading ranging from 0.3 to 3.3 wt.%. Two different molybdenum species were detected in these catalysts: tetrahedral monomeric Mo(VI) species and octahedral coordinated polymolybdate species.\"\n          [3] \"For molybdenum loading higher than 1.3 wt.%, polymolybdate species are predominant causing a decrease in the dispersion and a partial blocking up of the HZSM-5 zeolite channels.\"\n          [4] \"A second catalyst series were prepared from HZSM-5 zeolite by aqueous impregnation and subsequent washing with an aqueous ammonia solution, yielding Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts with Mo contents ranging from 0.08 to 0.45 wt.%. A well-dispersed molybdenum oxide phase mainly constituted of tetrahedral monomeric species joined to the zeolite surface was characterized.\"\n          [5] \"Both catalyst series show different activity in methane conversion. Polymolybdate species of impregnated Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts are more reactive in methane activation than acid sites of HZSM-5 but lead to low HCOH selectivity values.\"\n          [6] \"In contrast, treated catalysts show lower methane conversion but higher HCOH selectivity. These results demonstrate the specificity of the Mo=O sites of monomeric species for HCOH production.\"", "English": "The composition and structure of metal-based catalysts, such as Mo/HZSM-5, influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. Two series of Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts were tested in the partial oxidation of methane to formaldehyde. The first series was prepared by conventional aqueous impregnation with ammonium heptamolybdate, resulting in two molybdenum species: tetrahedral monomeric Mo(VI) species and octahedral coordinated polymolybdate species. For molybdenum loading higher than 1.3 wt.%, polymolybdate species are predominant, causing a decrease in dispersion and partial blocking of the HZSM-5 zeolite channels. The second series was prepared by aqueous impregnation and subsequent washing with an aqueous ammonia solution, yielding a well-dispersed molybdenum oxide phase mainly constituted of tetrahedral monomeric species. The two catalyst series show different activity in methane conversion. Polymolybdate species are more reactive in methane activation but lead to low formaldehyde selectivity values. In contrast, treated catalysts show lower methane conversion but higher formaldehyde selectivity, demonstrating the specificity of the Mo=O sites of monomeric species for formaldehyde production.", "Doi": "10.1016/s0926-860x(00)00472-5"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "The literature does not provide specific information on how the composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations, particularly in processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions. However, it does discuss the use of zeolites as catalysts for selective oxidation reactions, particularly the oxidative hydroxylation of aromatics using dinitrogen monoxide. The best results were obtained for the oxidation of benzene to phenol over Fe-containing ZSM-5 zeolites, which proceeds with nearly 100% selectivity at 25-30% benzene conversion. The efficiency of these catalysts is influenced by the nature of catalytic activity of zeolites, the role of iron, the chemical composition of the zeolite matrix, and the specific features of dinitrogen monoxide as an oxidant. Further progress in this promising direction, the hydroxylation of aromatics, can provide new efficient technologies in organic synthesis.", "Doi": "10.1016/0926-860x(93)85021-g"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The catalytic dehydrocondensation of methane to benzene and naphthalene with a bulky of hydrogen on transition metal supported zeolite catalysts is one of strategies for the catalytic conversion of methane and a challenging topic in heterogeneous catalysis.\"\n          [2] \"The results of investigation on the carbonaceous deposits and the synergetic effect between the transition metal components and the zeolite supports, as well as, the active species and reaction mechanisms are revealed by the TPO/XPS/FT-IR/EXAFS and solid NMR studies.\"\n          [3] \"Many processes related with methane conversion,whether direct or indirect route, require the use of oxygen, so the deep oxidation of methane is unavoidable.\"\n          [4] \"In order to suppress the formation of undesirable products such as CO and CO2, many researchers tried to transform methane into higher hydrocarbons in the absence of oxygen.\"\n          [5] \"It is generally accepted that the Mo/HZSM-5 is one of the good catalysts as reported by groups of Xu and co-workers [13,14], Chen et al. [15], Solymosi et al. [1619], Wang et al. [20,21],and Liu et al. [22,23].\"\n          [6] \"The improvement in enhancing activity or stability has been obtained by addition with Fe, Co, W, Zr, Ru and Cu [22,2831].\"\n          [7] \"During the past 8 years, the catalyst modification in term of zeolite micropores was extensively studied [23,3237].\"\n          [8] \"The indirect processes rely upon the production of synthesis gas, either by reforming reaction or by partial oxidation, followed by FischerTropsch chemistry.\"\n          [9] \"For the latter transformation route, methane can be converted to the desired products, e.g. ethylene, methanol, formaldehyde, and aromatics, directly.\"\n          [10] \"The oxidative coupling of methane as an alternative route for the direct conversion of methane had been extensively studied since 1982.\"\n          [11] \"Mitchell and Wanyhorne [8] reported that methane could be activated over M/MOn/MO multi-component catalyst at 977 K to form benzene and/or the carbonaceous deposit.\"\n          [12] \"Belgued et al. [11] reported that methane could be transformed to benzene in a flow mode reactor on transition metal ions supported HZSM-5 catalysts under non-oxidative condition.\"\n          [15] \"Weckhuysen et al. [26] studied the effect of transition metal ions, the preparation and treatment method.\"\n          [16] \"They found that the activity is in the following sequence: Mo > W > Fe > V > Cr.\"\n          [17] \"Later, Zeng et al. [27] reported the WH2SO4/HZSM-5 was a good catalyst for methane aromatization at 1123 K, however,the formation of coke was neglected.\"\n          [18] \"On the other hand, it should be noted that the addition of a sec- ond metal component is also studied as shown in [12].\"\n          [19] \"The splitting of CH bond is likely from the interaction between CH4 and the surface oxygen species [5].\"\n          [20] \"The direct transformation route for the formation of methanol and formaldehyde [24].\"\n          [21] \"Zeng et al. [27] reported the WH2SO4/HZSM-5 was a good catalyst for methane aromatization at 1123 K, however,the formation of coke was neglected.\"\n          [22] \"Zhang et al. studied the methane aromatization over Mo-based catalysts supported on different types of zeolites [32].\"", "English": "The catalytic dehydrocondensation of methane to benzene and naphthalene on transition metal supported zeolite catalysts is a strategy for the catalytic conversion of methane. The investigation of carbonaceous deposits, the synergetic effect between the transition metal components and the zeolite supports, the active species and reaction mechanisms are revealed by various studies. Many processes related to methane conversion require the use of oxygen, leading to the deep oxidation of methane. Researchers have tried to transform methane into higher hydrocarbons in the absence of oxygen to suppress the formation of undesirable products. Mo/HZSM-5 is generally accepted as a good catalyst for this process. The addition of Fe, Co, W, Zr, Ru and Cu can enhance the activity or stability of the catalyst. The catalyst modification in terms of zeolite micropores has been extensively studied. The indirect processes for methane conversion rely upon the production of synthesis gas, followed by Fischer-Tropsch chemistry. Methane can be directly converted to desired products such as ethylene, methanol, formaldehyde, and aromatics. The oxidative coupling of methane as an alternative route for direct conversion has been extensively studied since 1982. Methane can be activated over multi-component catalysts to form benzene and carbonaceous deposits. Methane can be transformed into higher hydrocarbons over supported Pt catalysts via a two-step route. Methane aromatization to benzene has been achieved over PtCrO3/HZSM-5 catalysts. Methane can be transformed to benzene in a flow mode reactor on transition metal ions supported HZSM-5 catalysts under non-oxidative conditions. The effect of transition metal ions, preparation, and treatment methods on catalysts has been studied. The activity of transition metal ions for methane aromatization follows the sequence: Mo > W > Fe > V > Cr. WH2SO4/HZSM-5 is a good catalyst for methane aromatization at high temperatures, but the formation of coke was neglected. The addition of a second metal component has been studied to enhance activity or stability. The splitting of the CH bond in methane is likely due to the interaction between CH4 and the surface oxygen species. The direct transformation route for the formation of methanol and formaldehyde has been explored. Methane aromatization over Mo-based catalysts supported on different types of zeolites has been investigated.", "Doi": "10.1016/s0920-5861(01)00440-0"},
{"Quotes": "\"[1] Supported vanadium oxides have been widely used as catalysts for a number of reactions. The molecular structure of the surface vanadium oxide species and the catalytic properties are influenced by the method of preparation, the nature of support, promotors and environmental conditions [1].\"\n          \"[2] Depending on the vanadium loadings, different vanadium oxide species (V5+) were formed on the surface of alumina after calcination. Mainly isolated and polymerized VO4 units were observed at coverages up to a monolayer [1,5,13] while VO6 octahedra were predominant on catalyst surfaces at higher vanadium loadings [1].\"\n          \"[3] The oxidative dehydrogenation of propane is a strong exothermic reaction and maximum temperatures of about 873 K or higher were observed in the catalytic bed using a more concentrated feed [26].\"\n          \"[4] The objective of the present work is, for that rea- son, the study of the nature and properties of the vanadium oxide species formed on the alumina support calcined at high temperature of 873 K at relatively high vanadium load- ings between 4.5 and 13.2 wt.% vanadium.\"\n          \"[5] The results of characterization will be compared with the catalytic performance in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane in order to get information about relations between phase composition, coordination,reducibility and dispersion of the vanadium species formed at high vanadium loading.\"\n          \"[6] The highest propene selectivity was obtained for the sample with the highest dispersion of the isolated and polymerized tetrahedrally coordinated V5+ species.\"\n          \"[7] It is suggested that both isolated and polymerized tetrahedrally coordinated V5+ species are active in propane dehydrogenation. Different vanadium oxide species (V5+) form on alumina surfaces depending on vanadium loadings, with isolated and polymerized VO4 units at lower coverages and VO6 octahedra at higher loadings. Propane oxidative dehydrogenation is strongly exothermic, with maximum temperatures around 873 K or higher observed in catalytic beds with concentrated feeds. Studies focus on the nature and properties of vanadium oxide species formed on alumina support at high temperatures and high vanadium loadings, relating phase composition, coordination, reducibility, and dispersion to catalytic performance. The highest propene selectivity is achieved with the highest dispersion of isolated and polymerized tetrahedrally coordinated V5+ species. Both isolated and polymerized tetrahedrally coordinated V5+ species are active in propane dehydrogenation, while the AlVO4 phase and bulk-like V2O5 have low catalytic activity. The portion of vanadium present as AlVO4 increases with increasing vanadium loadings.", "Doi": "10.1016/j.apcata.2004.05.050"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations, particularly in processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions. The introduction of metals such as Ga, Fe, and Zn into HZSM-5 cavities by sublimation results in the formation of various active species, including oxo ions like (GaO)+ and (HOFeOFeOH)2+, which are identified by temperature-programmed reduction with H2 and CO, and in the case of the binuclear Fe3+ ion, by ESR spectroscopy. These species contribute to the acidity of the catalysts, with the ratio of Lewis to Brnsted acid sites increasing in the sequence HZSM-5 < Ga/ZSM-5 < Fe/ZSM-5 < Zn/ZSM-5. The presence of these active species and the resulting acidity are crucial for the efficiency of alkane transformations. The industrial significance of these catalysts is attributed to their ability to catalyze reactions such as the MTG process, the manufacture of olefins from methanol, and the aromatization of light alkanes, which are important in the petrochemical industry. The introduction of metals like Ga, Fe, and Zn into HZSM-5 zeolites by sublimation leads to the formation of strong Lewis acid sites and the regeneration of Brnsted acid sites, which are crucial for catalytic activity. The strength and density of these acid sites, as well as the stability and reducibility of the metal species, play a critical role in the selectivity and conversion of alkanes. The industrial significance of these catalysts is attributed to their ability to catalyze reactions like the MTG process, the manufacture of olefins from methanol, and the aromatization of light alkanes, which are essential for the petrochemical industry. The introduction of metals such as Ga, Fe, and Zn into HZSM-5 cavities by sublimation results in the formation of strong Lewis acid sites and the regeneration of Brnsted acid sites, which are crucial for catalytic activity. The strength and density of these acid sites, as well as the presence of metal ions in various coordination environments, play a critical role in the selectivity and conversion of alkanes. The industrial significance of these catalysts is attributed to their ability to catalyze reactions under mild conditions, reduce energy consumption, and increase product yields, making them economically viable for large-scale production processes. The introduction of metals such as Ga, Fe, and Zn into HZSM-5 zeolites by sublimation results in the formation of strong Lewis acid sites and the regeneration of Brnsted acid sites, which can be stronger or weaker depending on the metal. The presence of these acid sites affects the catalytic activity and selectivity in alkane transformations. The reaction conditions, such as temperature and the presence of reducing or oxidizing atmospheres, can also influence the nature of the active species and thus the catalytic performance. The industrial significance of these catalysts lies in their ability to catalyze reactions such as the MTG process, the manufacture of olefins from methanol, and the aromatization of light alkanes, which are important in the petrochemical industry. The introduction of metals such as Ga, Fe, and Zn into HZSM-5 cavities by sublimation results in the formation of various active species, including binuclear Fe3+ ions, (GaO)+ ions, and Zn2+ cations, which can compensate the charge of two Al-centered tetrahedra or attach themselves to one silanol group or ZnOH and one Al-centered tetrahedron. These species contribute to the acidity of the catalysts, with the ratio of Lewis to Brnsted sites increasing in the sequence HZSM-5 < Ga/ZSM-5 < Fe/ZSM-5 < Zn/ZSM-5. The strength of these Lewis sites also increases in the order Al > Ga > Zn > Fe. The presence of these active species and the resulting acidity are crucial for the efficiency of alkane transformations in processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions. The industrial significance of these catalysts is due to their ability to catalyze the conversion of alkanes into more valuable products, such as olefins and aromatics, which are essential in the petrochemical industry.", "Doi": "10.1021/jp990116l"},

indicates that the reaction between the complex and the surface OH groups al- lows us to obtain highly dispersed oxo species, and this behavior was different from that found when an aqueous
